creditline: Museum purchase, Fowler McCormick, Class of 1921, Fund
markings:
Stamp on left: American Scenery
Stamp on right: Subscription Series
inscribed: Handwritten in ink on verso, lower right: New South / Family Circle

texts.textentryhtml: [Lee Gallery, Winchester, MA]; purchased by the Princeton University Art Museum, 2017.

This photograph is a stereograph, a format that places two images taken at slightly different angles side by side on a single card. When viewed through a binocular device called a stereoscope, the two images coalesce into one, producing an illusion of three-dimensionality. Commercially produced photographs like this one exemplify Northern whites’ demand for images of Southern Black life in the period following the Civil War. Inexpensive and popular, they catered to a variety of interests by depicting a range of subjects and genres, especially images of agricultural labor and scenes from domestic life. 

During the postbellum era, white audiences were especially interested in scenes of Black domestic life, motivating photographers to stage intimate moments for widespread consumption. Here, the photographer gathered a family on the porch of their home. The family is shown with solemn facial expressions and wearing tattered clothing. The depiction of their hardship perpetuates visual motifs, including ragged garments and modest dwellings, that were used to depict enslaved Black people in the preceding decades. Such images served to satisfy white audiences’ interest in liberated Black Americans while holding on to stereotypical notions of Black people as inevitably impoverished.

These photographs, taken after the Emancipation Proclamation of 1863, were produced primarily for a white audience interested in the lives of liberated African Americans. Clearly staging his subjects, the anonymous photographer created images that imagine Black freedom through visual motifs similar to those used to depict enslaved people. These prints are chillingly reminiscent of life before emancipation, with Family on porch, mother breastfeeding and Negro Cabin both similar to photographs of plantation life, glossing over the raw reality of hardship etched in the subjects’ solemn faces and tattered clothing. Meanwhile, Stereograph of Composition of 224 depicts African American sharecroppers picking cotton. Sharecropping kept Black families indebted for generations to white landowning families. It was a precarious economic existence, exacerbated by high interest rates, unpredictable harvests, and harsh working conditions. Despite promises of change, in these photographs progress appears to be a distant dream.


Natalie Bahrami, Class of 2021
texts.remarks: K2 Corridor: Transforming Landscapes: Memory and Slavery across the Americas (group chat for 2017-44, 2017-46, and ui. 2012.1474)

caption: Unknown American photographer, Family on porch, mother breastfeeding, 1860s–90s. Albumen print; 9.7 × 14.7 cm (image). Museum purchase, Fowler McCormick, Class of 1921, Fund (2017-46)
